ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have gained writing skills, public speaking skills, and the ability to manage a college workload.
I learned about the foundations of moral psychology and moral philosophy. I also learned more about what moral attitudes I hold and I enjoyed seeing how my moral ideas compared with my peers'.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths included: Student-teacher interaction, expression of ideas, varied subjects of study, interesting coursework.

Weaknesses: Grading

I think that the TF, Julia Marshall, was stellar. If possible, the TF for this course should be just as experienced, knowledgeable, and efficient during conference calls as she was. 

The course could be improved by talking about concrete ways that the principles of moral philosophy/psychology have tangibly affected laws (religious or governmental).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! I loved exploring big moral questions in an academic but not competitive, pressured, or judgmental environment.

extras.title:
PSYC S152E 01/CGSC S152E 01/PHIL S152E 01
        Moralities of Everyday Life
